thread.title: Violence and chaos erupt at UC-Berkeley in protest against Milo Yiannopoulos
thread.title_full: Violence and chaos erupt at UC-Berkeley in protest against Milo Yiannopoulos

author: USATODAY College
title: Violence and chaos erupt at UC-Berkeley in protest against Milo Yiannopoulos
text:
— Michael Bodley (@michael_bodley) February 2, 2017 
Law enforcement in riot gear was said to be using rubber bullets and tear gas on the crowd of protesters, according to multiple news reporters. Police in riot gear inside. This is pretty crazy. #Milo pic.twitter.com/1pKVY0BZyQ 
— Michael Bodley (@michael_bodley) February 2, 2017 Multiple dispersal orders have been given for the Milo protest. Please leave campus or avoid the area. @UCBerkeley #miloatcal 
— UC Police, Berkeley (@UCPD_Cal) February 2, 2017 The police release tear gas and shoot rubber bullets at the crowd. #MiloAtCal pic.twitter.com/Ej6rmpxGTf 
— Malini Ramaiyer (@malinisramaiyer) February 2, 2017 
The protest was originally scheduled as follows, according to the Berkeley Against Trump website : 
5pm – 7pm: Gathering of students, workers, faculty and community at the MLK Student Union building @ Bancroft and Telegraph. * The MLK Student Union building will close for the day at 4pm. 
6pm: Queer and Trans Dance Party @ Sproul Plaza.*organized through Facebook by an allied group. 
7pm: doors open for the Milo event. 
8pm: Milo’s event is scheduled to begin. 
The group’s intent was to speak out against Yiannopoulos, a self-proclaimed “troll” and editor for Breitbart News . Yiannopoulos is permanently banned from Twitter due to his role in a campaign against Leslie Jones , a Saturday Night Live actress. 
“We are here to protest the presence of Milo in our campus, which is a public university, and we believe that no hate speech, racism, misogyny and transphobia should be tolerated here,” the group posted. 
As the Daily Californian , UC-Berkeley’s newspaper, reported , at about 7:30 p.m., police started shooting tear gas into the crowd from a vantage point on the student union building. A half hour later, the protest was still going strong. Woman gets beaten by protestors at UC Berkeley #MiloAtCal pic.twitter.com/3GukFvAXmH 
— #HeWillNotDivideUs (@HWNDUS) February 2, 2017 
UC-Berkeley estimated the crowd to be about 1,500 strong. The university released a statement regarding the violent protests: 
“We condemn in the strongest possible terms the violence and unlawful behavior that was on display and deeply regret that those tactics will now overshadow the efforts to engage in legitimate and lawful protest against the performer’s presence and perspectives.” 
Yiannopoulos went live on Facebook to denounce what he views as the shutting down of his free speech. Chelsie Arnold is a student at Eastern New Mexico University and a USA TODAY College digital producer.
